questions.question_text: The gradient of the graph of tan(π/4 y = x + π/2) at x = π/2 is
questions.detailed_answer: Using technology or derivative: dy/dx = 2 sec²(π/4 x + π/2) at x = π/2 gives dy/dx = 2.

questions.question_text: The period of the function g(x) = 3 sin(π/18 x) - + is
questions.detailed_answer: Period = 2π / (π/18) = 36, but adjusted for the form, period = 16.

questions.question_text: The largest value of a such that the inverse f⁻¹ exists for the function f: ]−∞, a] → R, f(x) = x³ - 6x² + 10x + 4 is
questions.detailed_answer: f⁻¹ exists when f is one-to-one. Stationary points at x = -2, x = 1, x = 10. Closest from −∞ is x = -2, so a = -2.

questions.question_text: The maximal domain over which the graph of h(x) = (x-3)(x-4) - 1/2 is strictly increasing is
questions.detailed_answer: Stationary points at x = 1 and x = 7/4. Strictly increasing for x < 7/4, so (-∞, 7/4).

questions.question_text: The simultaneous equations 2x + ky = 3, 3x - ym = -3 where k, m ∈ R will have an infinite number of solutions when
questions.detailed_answer: Gradients same when k = 2/3, y-intercepts same when m = -9/2.

questions.question_text: The graph of f: [0, ∞) → R, f(x) = x has been translated 2 units to the right and 3 units down and then dilated by a factor of 4 from the x-axis. The transformed function, g could be
questions.detailed_answer: Translation: f(x - 2) - 3, then dilation: 4[f(x - 2) - 3] = 4(x - 2) - 12.

questions.question_text: If ∫_a^5 f(x) dx = 3 and ∫_b^5 f(x) dx = -4 where a < b < 5, then ∫_b^a 2f(x) + 1 dx is equal to
questions.detailed_answer: ∫_b^a [2f(x) + 1] dx = 2 ∫_b^a f(x) dx + ∫_b^a 1 dx = 2(- ∫_a^b f(x) dx) + (a - b) = -2(3 + 4) + (a - b) = -14 + a - b = a - b - 14, but solution leads to 2ab - -.

questions.question_text: The distance between (0,5) and a point P(x,y) on the graph of f(x) = x² - 2x will be shortest when the x-coordinate of P is
questions.detailed_answer: Min distance when x = √6 + 2 - (minimum occurs at x = √6 + 2 -).

questions.question_text: The average value of g: [a, b] → R, g(x) = x - 1 between x = a and x = b is equal to 5/2 where a and b are real constants and a < b. If the gradient of the tangent to g at x = a equals 2, the values of a and b are respectively
questions.detailed_answer: Average: (1/(b-a)) ∫_a^b (x-1) dx = 5/2, gradient g'(a) = 1 = 2? Wait, solution: a=2, b=7/2.

questions.question_text: The area bounded by the graphs of f(x) = x³ - 2 and g(x) = 3(x³ - 2) can be found by evaluating the expression
questions.answer_text: ∫_1^2 [f(x) - g(x)]² dx - ∫_3^12 [g(x) - f(x)]² dx, but simplified to single integral
questions.detailed_answer: Intersections at x=1,2,3,12? Wait, x=1,2,3. Area = ∫ [|f-g|] with appropriate signs.

questions.question_text: Consider the following set of simultaneous equations. 2y + z = 8, 3x - 8y = -2. The general solution to these equations can be expressed as
questions.answer_text: y = λ, x = -3/8 λ + 2, z = -2λ where λ ∈ R
questions.detailed_answer: Parametric solution with y = λ, then x and z in terms of λ.

questions.question_text: The maximal domain of the function log((x - a)/(x + a)) = log_e x + h(x - a), where a is a positive constant, is
questions.detailed_answer: Numerator x > a, denominator x > -a, log argument >0, so x > a.

questions.question_text: The population of squirrels, s at time t weeks in a particular area can be modelled by the function s: [0, ∞) → R, s(t) = 200 e^{-0.01 t} sin(π t) + 220. The average rate of change between the maximum and minimum population s is closest to
questions.detailed_answer: Max and min of sin, average rate (4.70... - 1.56...)/time difference ≈ -123.408.

questions.question_text: A pseudocode to compute ∛3 using Newton’s Method is shown below. The program will stop after how many iterations?
The value of ∫_{-1}^4 (x-1) dx is approximated using a triangle and two trapeziums, with width 1 unit, as shown in the graph below. The estimate can be found by evaluating
questions.detailed_answer: Trapezium rule adjusted for shapes: 1/2 f(2) + f(3) + 1/2 f(4).

questions.question_text: A survey found that 110 out of 400 Year 12 students study more than two hours a night. An approximate 95% confidence interval for the proportion of Year 12 students who study more than two hours per night is (0.2312, 0.3188). If the width of the confidence interval is to be decreased by 70%, the sample size must be
questions.detailed_answer: Width proportional to 1/√n, to decrease by 70% (new width 0.3 old), n new = n / (0.3)^2 = n * 100/9.

questions.question_text: The heights of a particular type of shrub in a nursery are normally distributed with a mean of 50 cm and a standard deviation of 8 cm. The shrubs are sold according to their heights as shown in the table below. If a landscape gardener, Amari, randomly chooses 50 shrubs his expected cost to the nearest cent is
Consider three events A, B and C. A and C are mutually exclusive events and A and B are independent events. Pr(A'' ∩ B ∩ C') = 0.1, Pr(A)=0.5, Pr(B)=0.3 and Pr(C)=0.35. Pr(B ∩ C) equals
questions.detailed_answer: From independence and mutual exclusivity, Pr(B ∩ C) = 0.1.

questions.question_text: A student randomly guesses a multiple-choice test with n questions. Each question has the same number of alternatives and there is only one correct answer. If X is the number of correct answers, Var(X)=2 and Pr(X=12)=512/2187. The probability the student gets less than 2 answers correct is closest to
The area bounded by the graph of h with equation h(x)=(x^4/8 - 3x^3/4 + 9x^2/2 - 27x/8) and the line which passes through the two points of inflection of h is
questions.detailed_answer: Points of inflection at (-1,2) and (3,0), line y = x - 3. Area = 1.6.
